Preserve and Restore NA Information Within a Vector

preserve_na.Rd

preserve_na() stores NA vector positions and extracts valid non-NA values for later restoration with restore_na().

restore_na() restores NA values to their original vector positions after processing valid non-NA values returned from preserve_na().

Usage

preserve_na(x)

restore_na(y, na_info)

Arguments

x

A vector containing missing NA values.

y

A vector of valid non-NA values returned from preserve_na().

na_info

A list returned from preserve_na().

Value

preserve_na() returns a list na_info with components:

  • na_info$x_valid: A vector with NA values removed.

  • na_info$x_length: A numeric value of the original input vector length.

  • na_info$na_idx: A logical vector preserving NA positions.

restore_na() returns a vector y of the same length as the original input vector x with NA values restored to their original positions.

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
x <- c(1, NA, 3, NA, 5)
na_info <- preserve_na(x)
## process with a function that would normally fail on NA
y <- na_info$x_valid * 2
result <- restore_na(y, na_info)
result

x <- c("A", NA, "B", NA, "C")
na_info <- preserve_na(x)
## process with a function that would normally fail on NA
y <- tolower(na_info$x_valid)
result <- restore_na(y, na_info)
result
} # }
